elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

A family of new coordination compounds constructed from 4'-((2-carboxyphenoxy)methyl)biphenyl-2-carboxylic acid and different N-donor ligands have been solvothermally synthesized and their photoluminescent properties have also been studied.

elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Ten coordination compounds, namely {[Cd(L)(die)]⋅2/3H2O} n  (1), [Cd(L)(dib)] n  (2), [Cd(L)(bmimb)] n  (3), {[Cd(L)(bimb)]⋅1/2EtOH} n  (4), [Zn(L)(bimb)] n  (5), [Co(L)(bimb)] n  (6), {[Cd(L)(phen)]⋅EtOH} n  (7), [Cu(L)(phen)] n  (8), [Zn(L)(mtpy)] n  (9) and [Ni(L)(mtpy)]⋅1/2H2O (10) (H2L=4'-((2-carboxyphenoxy)methyl)biphenyl-2-carboxylic acid, die=1,2-di(1H-imidazol-1-yl)ethane, dib=1,4-di(1H-imidazol-1-yl)butane, bmimb=1,4-bis((2-methyl-1H-imidazol-1-yl)methyl)benzene, bimb=1,4-bis((1H-imidazol-1-yl)methyl)benzene, phen=1,10-phenanthroline and mtpy=4'-(4-methylphenyl)-2,2':6',2"-terpyridine), have been solvothermally synthesized. These compounds were characterized by X-ray crystallography, elemental analysis, infrared spectra (IR) and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD). In compounds 1-3, similar dimeric [Cd2(L)2] units are connected by different N-donor ligands to form diverse architectures. Strikingly, compound 3 displays a 2D→3D interdigitated framework. Compounds 4-6 are essentially isostructural and reveal 2D sheet structures. Compound 7 shows a 2D 44-sql network stabilized by π-π interactions between the pyridine rings of the phen ligands. Compound 8 exhibits a 3D supramolecular architecture constructed from a 1D chain via π-π interactions. Compound 9 possesses a 1D chain structure, which is further extended into a 2D supramolecular layer through hydrogen-bonding interactions. Compound 10 displays a [Cd2(L)2(mtpy)2] dimeric structure. Adjacent dimers further interact through hydrogen-bonding interactions to afford a 1D supramolecular chain. Moreover, the luminescent properties of 1-5, 7 and 9 have also been investigated in this work.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st020">Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">In recent years, the exploratory synthesis and research on coordination compounds (CCs) based on assembly of metal ions and multifunctional organic ligands have been an attractive field because of their attractive topologies and potential applications . Experimental studies reveal that the construction of CCs is influenced by several factors, such as pH value, reaction temperature, central metal, ligand to metal ratio and the organic ligand . Especially, the organic ligands play an important role in the formation of the final complex architectures . Therefore, the rational design and employment of organic ligands are an effective strategy for the construction of the desired CCs. So far, various multicarboxylate ligands have been used to construct a large number of CCs with abundant motifs, including honeycomb, brick wall, bilayer, ladder, herringbone, diamond and rectangular grid . Among these known CCs, entangled structures, such as interpenetration, polycatenation and interdigitated supramolecular architecture, have attracted particular attention . In this regard, the 2D<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3D interdigitated supermolecular architecture held together by weak <ce:italic>π</ce:italic>–<ce:italic>π</ce:italic> interactions is less explored .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In recent years, the exploratory synthesis and research on coordination compounds (CCs) based on assembly of metal ions and multifunctional organic ligands have been an attractive field because of their attractive topologies and potential applications . Experimental studies reveal that the construction of CCs is influenced by several factors, such as pH value, reaction temperature, central metal, ligand to metal ratio and the organic ligand . Especially, the organic ligands play an important role in the formation of the final complex architectures . Therefore, the rational design and employment of organic ligands are an effective strategy for the construction of the desired CCs. So far, various multicarboxylate ligands have been used to construct a large number of CCs with abundant motifs, including honeycomb, brick wall, bilayer, ladder, herringbone, diamond and rectangular grid . Among these known CCs, entangled structures, such as interpenetration, polycatenation and interdigitated supramolecular architecture, have attracted particular attention . In this regard, the 2D→3D interdigitated supermolecular architecture held together by weak π-π interactions is less explored .

The flexible “–H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C–O–” spacer as a “free-spinning” point can make two carboxyl groups coordinate to metal ions in different directions. <ce:float-anchor refid="f0070"></ce:float-anchor>), have been solvothermally synthesized. elements.clean_text: In this work, we synthesized a new multicarboxylate ligand, 4'-((2-carboxyphenoxy)methyl)biphenyl-2-carboxylic acid (H2L). The flexible "-H2C-O-" spacer as a "free-spinning" point can make two carboxyl groups coordinate to metal ions in different directions. Based on H2L, ten new CCs, namely {[Cd(L)(die)]⋅2/3H2O} n  (1), [Cd(L)(dib)] n  (2), [Cd(L)(bmimb)] n  (3), {[Cd(L)(bimb)]⋅1/2EtOH} n  (4), [Zn(L)(bimb)] n  (5), [Co(L)(bimb)] n  (6), {[Cd(L)(phen)]⋅EtOH} n  (7), [Cu(L)(phen)] n  (8), [Zn(L)(mtpy)] n  (9) and [Ni(L)(mtpy)]⋅1/2H2O (10), where die=1,2-di(1H-imidazol-1-yl)ethane, dib=1,4-di(1H-imidazol-1-yl)butane, bmimb=1,4-bis((2-methyl-1H-imidazol-1-yl)methyl)benzene, bimb=1,4-bis((1H-imidazol-1-yl)methyl)benzene, phen=1,10-phenanthroline and mtpy=4'-(4-methylphenyl)-2,2':6',2"-terpyridine ( ), have been solvothermally synthesized. All the compounds were characterized by X-ray crystallography, elemental analyses, infrared spectra (IR) and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD). The effects of the N-donor ligands and metal cations on the final structures have been discussed. Furthermore, the luminescent properties of 1-5, 7 and 9 have also been investigated.

<ce:section-title id="st025">Experimental section</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st030">Materials and methods</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0015" view="all">The N-donor ligands were prepared according to the reported procedures . All other chemicals and solvents used in the syntheses were of analytical grade and used without further purification. PXRD patterns were conducted on a Rigaku Dmax 2000 X-ray diffractometer with graphite monochromatized Cu Kα radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.154<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm) with 2<ce:italic>θ</ce:italic> ranging from 5° to 50°. The C, H and N elemental analyses were measured on a Perkin–Elmer 2400 elemental analyzer. IR spectra were carried out on a Mattson Alpha-Centauri spectrometer in the range 4000–400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. The luminescent properties of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>7</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>9</ce:bold> were measured on an FLSP920 Edinburgh Fluorescence spectrometer at room temperature.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental section

Materials and methods

The N-donor ligands were prepared according to the reported procedures . All other chemicals and solvents used in the syntheses were of analytical grade and used without further purification. PXRD patterns were conducted on a Rigaku Dmax 2000 X-ray diffractometer with graphite monochromatized Cu Kα radiation (λ =0.154nm) with 2θ ranging from 5° to 50°. The C, H and N elemental analyses were measured on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 elemental analyzer. IR spectra were carried out on a Mattson Alpha-Centauri spectrometer in the range 4000-400cm-1. The luminescent properties of compounds 1-5, 7 and 9 were measured on an FLSP920 Edinburgh Fluorescence spectrometer at room temperature.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st035">Syntheses of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L and the complexes</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st040">Synthesis of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0020" view="all">A mixture of 2-hydroxy benzoic acid methyl ester (4.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), NaOH (0.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), 4-bromomethylbiphenyl-2′-carboxylic acid methyl ester (7.7<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and ethanol (100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) was refluxed for 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. The solution was cooled to room temperature, and NaOH (2.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) dissolved in water (30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) was added. elements.clean_text:
Syntheses of H2L and the complexes

Synthesis of H2L

A mixture of 2-hydroxy benzoic acid methyl ester (4.2g, 10mmol), NaOH (0.4g, 10mmol), 4-bromomethylbiphenyl-2'-carboxylic acid methyl ester (7.7g, 10mmol) and ethanol (100mL) was refluxed for 10h. The solution was cooled to room temperature, and NaOH (2.0g, 50mmol) dissolved in water (30mL) was added. After the mixture was refluxed for 8h, the alcohol was removed by rotary evaporation, then 150mL water was added and the pH value was adjusted to 2-3 using hydrochloric acid. The solid H2L was filtered off, washed with water and air-dried (yield 63%). Mp: 176.4-177.8°C. Anal. Calc. for C21H16O5 (M r =348.35): C, 72.41; H, 4.63. Found: C, 72.30; H, 4.77%. IR (cm-1): 3062(s), 1695(w), 1605(w), 1486(m), 1299(w), 1258(m), 866(s), 821(m). 1H NMR [500MHz, (CD3)2SO] δ, ppm: 5.24 (s, 2H), 7.02 (t, 1H), 7.23 (d, 1H), 7.34 (d, 2H), 7.39 (d, 1H), 7.45 (t, 1H), 7.49 (d, 1H), 7.52 (d, 2H), 7.58 (t, 1H), 7.66 (d, 1H), 7.71 (d, 1H), 12.71 (s, 2H).

elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Description of the crystal structures

Structure of {[Cd(L)(die)]⋅2/3H2O} n  (1)

Single-crystal X-ray structural analysis shows that the asymmetric unit of 1 contains one Cd(II) cation, one L anion, one die ligand and two thirds of a lattice water molecule. As shown in  a, each Cd(II) atom is four-coordinated by two carboxylate oxygen atoms from two L anions (Cd1-O1=2.254(3), Cd(1)-O(4)#2 =2.254(2)Å) and two nitrogen atoms from two die ligands (Cd(1)-N(1)=2.208(3), Cd(1)-N(4)#1 =2.201(3)Å) in a distorted tetrahedral environment. In 1-4 and 7, the Cd-O and Cd-N bond distances are in the normal range as found in related complexes . Each L anion bridges two Cd(II) atoms in a μ 2-η1:η0:η1:η0 coordination mode (mode I in  ). In this manner, two adjacent Cd(II) ions are bridged by two L ligands to generate a dimeric [Cd2(L)2] unit with a Cd⋯Cd distance of 7.416Å (b). Each [Cd2(L)2] dimer connects four adjacent [Cd2(L)2] dimers through four die ligands to yield a 2D sheet structure (c), where the Cd⋯Cd distance bridged by the die ligand is 6.347Å.

<ce:section-title id="st115">Structure of [Cd(L)(dib)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0085" view="all">When dib was utilized in the place of die, a similar compound, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, was obtained under similar synthetic conditions. Single-crystal X-ray structural analysis reveals that the asymmetric unit of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is composed of one Cd(II) atom, one L anion and one dib ligand. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>a, each Cd(II) ion is four-coordinated by two carboxylate oxygen atoms from two L anions (Cd(1)–O(3)<ce:sup loc="post">#1</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.281(4), Cd(1)–O(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.217(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) and two nitrogen atoms from two dib ligands (Cd(1)–N(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.214(3), Cd(1)–N(4)<ce:sup loc="post">#2</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.218(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) in a distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry. Each L anion, in the <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">0</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">0</ce:sup> coordination mode, bridges two Cd(II) atoms to yield a [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] dimer (mode I in ). The Cd(II)⋯Cd(II) distance separated by the L anion is 7.622<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, which is similar to that of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. Dib ligands in bis-monodentate coordination mode bridge the Cd(II) atoms of the [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] dimers, resulting in a 2D layer (b). The Cd⋯Cd distance spanned by the dib ligand of 13.567<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å is much longer than that found in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (6.347<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Structure of [Cd(L)(dib)] n  (2)

When dib was utilized in the place of die, a similar compound, 2, was obtained under similar synthetic conditions. Single-crystal X-ray structural analysis reveals that the asymmetric unit of 2 is composed of one Cd(II) atom, one L anion and one dib ligand. As shown in  a, each Cd(II) ion is four-coordinated by two carboxylate oxygen atoms from two L anions (Cd(1)-O(3)#1 =2.281(4), Cd(1)-O(1)=2.217(3)Å) and two nitrogen atoms from two dib ligands (Cd(1)-N(1)=2.214(3), Cd(1)-N(4)#2 =2.218(3)Å) in a distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry. Each L anion, in the μ 2-η1:η0:η1:η0 coordination mode, bridges two Cd(II) atoms to yield a [Cd2(L)2] dimer (mode I in ). The Cd(II)⋯Cd(II) distance separated by the L anion is 7.622Å, which is similar to that of 1. Dib ligands in bis-monodentate coordination mode bridge the Cd(II) atoms of the [Cd2(L)2] dimers, resulting in a 2D layer (b). The Cd⋯Cd distance spanned by the dib ligand of 13.567Å is much longer than that found in 1 (6.347Å).

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st120">Structure of [Cd(L)(bmimb)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0090" view="all">When bmimb was used, compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> was obtained under similar synthetic conditions. Single-crystal X-ray structural analysis reveals that the asymmetric unit of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> consists of one Cd(II) atom, one L anion and two half bmimb ligands. The Cd1 atom is five-coordinated by three carboxylate oxygen atoms from two L anions (Cd(1)–O(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.221(6), Cd(1)–O(1)<ce:sup loc="post">#1</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.388(5), Cd(1)–O(2)<ce:sup loc="post">#1</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.346(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) and two nitrogen atoms from two bmimb ligands (Cd(1)–N(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.241(5), Cd(1)–N(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.223(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) in a distorted trigonal bipyramidal geometry (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>a). Two Cd(II) ions are linked by two L anions to form a [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] dimeric unit. The cyclic [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] dimeric unit is similar to the ones observed in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. Different from <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the L anions adopt the <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">0</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup> coordination mode in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> (mode II in ). The Cd(II)⋯Cd(II) distance in the [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] dimer of 7.991<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å is longer than those observed in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. Each bmimb ligand links two [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] dimers to afford a 2D layer (b). The Cd⋯Cd distance separated by bmimb ligand of 14.945<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å is slightly longer than that found in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (13.567<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), but is much longer than that observed in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (6.347<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). The lengthened Cd⋯Cd separation by the bmimb ligand in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is mainly ascribed to the increasing spacer length between the two imidazole groups. Notably, the large interstices between the two [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] dimers provide the chance for interdigitation between adjacent layers. As a result, the [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] dimers from one layer penetrate into adjacent layers, resulting in a 2D<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3D interdigitated architecture (c and ], which is stabilized by <ce:italic>π</ce:italic>–<ce:italic>π</ce:italic> interactions between two phenyl groups of the L ligands (the two phenyl groups are composed of C2–C7 and C2<ce:sup loc="post">#4</ce:sup>–C7<ce:sup loc="post">#4</ce:sup>. symmetry code: <ce:sup loc="post">#4</ce:sup> −<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1, −<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1), with a face-to-face distance of 3.544<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and centroid-to-centroid distance of 3.652<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å.</ce:para>

Structure of [Cd(L)(bmimb)] n  (3)

When bmimb was used, compound 3 was obtained under similar synthetic conditions. Single-crystal X-ray structural analysis reveals that the asymmetric unit of 3 consists of one Cd(II) atom, one L anion and two half bmimb ligands. The Cd1 atom is five-coordinated by three carboxylate oxygen atoms from two L anions (Cd(1)-O(4)=2.221(6), Cd(1)-O(1)#1 =2.388(5), Cd(1)-O(2)#1 =2.346(5)Å) and two nitrogen atoms from two bmimb ligands (Cd(1)-N(3)=2.241(5), Cd(1)-N(1)=2.223(5)Å) in a distorted trigonal bipyramidal geometry ( a). Two Cd(II) ions are linked by two L anions to form a [Cd2(L)2] dimeric unit. The cyclic [Cd2(L)2] dimeric unit is similar to the ones observed in 1 and 2. Different from 1 and 2, the L anions adopt the μ 2-η1:η0:η1:η1 coordination mode in 3 (mode II in ). The Cd(II)⋯Cd(II) distance in the [Cd2(L)2] dimer of 7.991Å is longer than those observed in 1 and 2. Each bmimb ligand links two [Cd2(L)2] dimers to afford a 2D layer (b). The Cd⋯Cd distance separated by bmimb ligand of 14.945Å is slightly longer than that found in 2 (13.567Å), but is much longer than that observed in 1 (6.347Å). The lengthened Cd⋯Cd separation by the bmimb ligand in 3 is mainly ascribed to the increasing spacer length between the two imidazole groups. Notably, the large interstices between the two [Cd2(L)2] dimers provide the chance for interdigitation between adjacent layers. As a result, the [Cd2(L)2] dimers from one layer penetrate into adjacent layers, resulting in a 2D→3D interdigitated architecture (c and ], which is stabilized by π-π interactions between two phenyl groups of the L ligands (the two phenyl groups are composed of C2-C7 and C2#4-C7#4. symmetry code: #4 -x +1, -y +1, -z +1), with a face-to-face distance of 3.544Å and centroid-to-centroid distance of 3.652Å.

Structure of {[Cd(L)(bimb)]⋅1/2EtOH} n  (4)

When bimb was used in the synthesis, the significantly different compound 4 was obtained. Single-crystal X-ray structural analysis exhibits that the asymmetric unit of 4 is composed of one Cd(II) atom, one L anion, one bimb ligand and half a lattice ethanol molecule. Each Cd(II) atom is five-coordinated by three carboxylate oxygen atoms from two L anions (Cd(1)-O(4)=2.230(9), Cd(1)-O(1)#1 =2.09(6), Cd(1)-O(2)#1 =2.37(7)Å) and two nitrogen atoms from two bimb ligands (Cd(1)-N(4)#2 =2.22(2), Cd(1)-N(1)=2.261(8)Å) in a distorted trigonal bipyramidal environment ( a). In 4, the L ligands in μ 2-η1:η0:η1:η1 coordination modes bridge adjacent Cd(II) atoms to generate a zigzag chain with a Cd⋯Cd distance of 8.831Å (b and mode II in ). Furthermore, the bimb ligands link adjacent chains to give a 2D sheet (c). The Cd⋯Cd distance spanned by the bimb ligand of 15.024Å is close to that found in 3.

Structures of [Zn(L)(bimb)] n  (5) and [Co(L)(bimb)] n  (6)

The structures of compounds 5 and 6 are essentially isomorphic with 4, apart from very slight differences (  ). First, the coordination number of the mental center is different. Both the Zn(II) atom in 5 and Co(II) atom in 6 are four-coordinated by two carboxylate oxygen atoms from two L anions (Zn(1)-O(1)#1 =1.948(3), Zn(1)-O(4)=1.956(7), Co(1)-O(4)=1.938(7), Co(1)-O(1)#1 =1.968(3)Å) and two nitrogen atoms from two bimb ligands (Zn(1)-N(1)=2.021(3), Zn(1)-N(4)#2 =2.021(4), Co(1)-N(1)=2.029(3), Co(1)-N(4)#2 =2.039(3)Å) in distorted tetrahedral geometries, whereas the Cd(II) atom in 4 is five-coordinated in a distorted trigonal bipyramidal geometry. All the Zn-O, Zn-N, Co-O and Co-N bond distances lie in the normal range . Second, the coordination modes of the L anions are different. The L ligand in 4 adopts the μ 2-η1:η0:η1:η1 coordination mode, while compounds 5 and 6 show a μ 2-η1:η0:η1:η0 coordination manner (mode I in ). Third, lattice ethanol molecules exist in 4.

Structure of {[Cd(L)(phen)]⋅EtOH} n  (7)

When the chelating phen ligand was utilized in place of the flexible ligand, compound 7 was generated. Single-crystal X-ray structural analysis shows that the asymmetric unit of 7 contains one Cd(II) atom, one L anion, one phen ligand and one lattice ethanol molecule. As shown in  a, each Cd(II) atom is five-coordinated by three carboxylate oxygen atoms from three L anions (Cd(1)-O(3)=2.251(3), Cd(1)-O(2)#1 =2.293(2), Cd(1)-O(1)#2 =2.310(3)Å) and two nitrogen atoms from one phen ligand (Cd(1)-N(2)=2.334(3), Cd(1)-N(1)=2.390(3)Å) in a distorted trigonal bipyramidal geometry. Each L anion exhibits a μ 3-η1:η1:η1:η0 coordination mode (mode III in ). Cd1 and its symmetry-related species are bridged by a carboxylate oxygen atom (O2) to form a binuclear [Cd2] unit (). Two phen ligands are located on both sides of the [Cd2] unit. In addition, the Cd⋯Cd distance is 3.844Å, which is similar to that observed in other [Cd2] units . The [Cd2] units are further linked by the backbones of L anions to form a 2D 44-sql network (b) . Moreover, π-π interactions between the pyridine rings of two phen ligands stabilize the 2D network (face-to-face and centroid-to-centroid distances of 3.496 and 3.821Å, respectively) (c).

The Cu1 atom is four-coordinated by two carboxylate oxygen atoms from two L anions (Cu(1)–O(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.930(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) and two nitrogen atoms from one phen ligand (Cu(1)–N(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.002(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) in a distorted tetrahedral geometry. Both the Cu–O and Cu–N bond distances are in the normal range . Adjacent Cu(II) atoms are linked by L anions in the <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">0</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">0</ce:sup> coordination mode to give a 1D left-handed helical chain (mode I in ), while the chelating phen ligands are located on both sides of the chain (b). Structure of [Cu(L)(phen)] n  (8)

Single-crystal X-ray analysis reveals that 8 crystallizes in the orthorhombic chiral space group C2221. As shown in  a, the asymmetric unit of 8 consists of half a Cu(II) atom, half a L anion and half a phen ligand. The Cu1 atom is four-coordinated by two carboxylate oxygen atoms from two L anions (Cu(1)-O(1)=1.930(3)Å) and two nitrogen atoms from one phen ligand (Cu(1)-N(1)=2.002(4)Å) in a distorted tetrahedral geometry. Both the Cu-O and Cu-N bond distances are in the normal range . Adjacent Cu(II) atoms are linked by L anions in the μ 2-η1:η0:η1:η0 coordination mode to give a 1D left-handed helical chain (mode I in ), while the chelating phen ligands are located on both sides of the chain (b). Moreover, there are π-π interactions between the phen ligands (C17, C18, C19, C17#1, C18#1 and C19#1) and L anions (C2-C7) with a face-to-face distance of 3.711Å and centroid-to-centroid distance of 3.739Å. These π-π interactions further link adjacent chains to yield a 3D supramolecular architecture (b).

Structure of [Zn(L)(mtpy)] n  (9)

Single-crystal X-ray structural analysis shows that the asymmetric unit of 9 is composed of one Zn(II) atom, one L anion and one mtpy ligand. Each Zn(II) cation is five-coordinated by two carboxylate oxygen atoms from two L anions (Zn(1)-O(2)=1.9286(19), Zn(1)-O(4)#1 =1.9883(18)Å) and three nitrogen atoms from one mtpy ligand (Zn(1)-N(2)=2.099(2), Zn(1)-N(3)=2.189(2), Zn(1)-N(1)=2.238(2)Å) in a distorted trigonal bipyramid coordination environment ( a). Each carboxylate group adopts a μ 1-η1:η0 coordination mode (mode I in ). In this way, adjacent Zn(II) atoms are linked via L anions to generate a 1D zigzag chain (b). The chelating mtpy ligands are located in the middle of the zigzag chain. Adjacent zigzag chains are further linked by intermolecular hydrogen-bonding interactions between the mtpy ligands and the carboxylate oxygen atoms (C35⋯O4#2 =3.506(3)Å; symmetry code: #2 x, -y -1/2, z -1/2), resulting in a 2D supramolecular architecture (c) . In addition, there are intramolecular (C32⋯O3=3.256(3), C40⋯O3=3.325(4) and C38⋯O1=2.999(4)Å) and intermolecular hydrogen-bonding interactions (C43⋯O3#3 =3.247(4)Å; symmetry code: #3 -x +1, y +1/2, -z +1/2), which further stabilize the 2D supramolecular layer ().

elements.clean_text:
Structure of [Ni(L)(mtpy)]⋅1/2H2O (10)

Single-crystal X-ray structural analysis reveals that the asymmetric unit of 10 consists of one Ni(II) atom, one L anion, one mtpy ligand and half a lattice water molecule. As shown in  a, each Ni(II) cation is six-coordinated by three carboxylate oxygen atoms from two L anions (Ni(1)-O(2)=1.997(3), Ni(1)-O(4)#1 =2.132(3), Ni(1)-O(3)#1 =2.178(3)Å) and three nitrogen atoms from one mtpy ligand (Ni(1)-N(2)=1.970(3), Ni(1)-N(3)=2.071(3), Ni(1)-N(1)=2.099(3)Å) in a distorted octahedral geometry. Both the Ni-O and Ni-N bond distances lie in the normal range . Two L anions in the μ 2-η1:η0:η1:η1 coordination mode bridge two Ni(II) atoms to generate a metallomacrocyclic structure (b and mode II in ). Further, hydrogen bonds between the carboxylate oxygen atoms and carbon atoms of mtpy are observed (C30⋯O1#2 =3.499(5) and C40⋯O1#2 =3.306(6)Å; symmetry code: #2 -x, -y, -z +1). These intermolecular hydrogen-bonding interactions further link the 0D structure into a 1D supramolecular chain (c). Moreover, the 1D supramolecular chains are stabilized by intramolecular hydrogen-bonding interactions (C35⋯O3=3.172(5)Å).

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st155">Effect of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L on the complex structures</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0125" view="all">The structural diversities of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>10</ce:bold> indicate that the coordination modes of the L anions have a significant effect on the final structures of the compounds. It is noteworthy that the flexible “–H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C–O–” spacer of the L anion could make the two carboxylate groups coordinate to metal ions in different directions. In compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>8</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>10</ce:bold>, although each L anion bridges two metal cations, the two carboxylates can twist to bridge metal ions in different directions. In compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>9</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>10</ce:bold>, the two carboxylates of each L anion link two metal ions in the same direction to form a dimeric unit. However, in compounds <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>8</ce:bold>, the two carboxylates of each L anion connect two metal ions in different directions, yielding chain structures. Meanwhile, in <ce:bold>7</ce:bold> the two carboxylates of each L anion bridge three metal ions to generate a 2D 4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>-sql network. Noticeably, the coordination modes of the L anions are a key factor that influences the final structures of these compounds.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Effect of H2L on the complex structures

The structural diversities of 1-10 indicate that the coordination modes of the L anions have a significant effect on the final structures of the compounds. It is noteworthy that the flexible "-H2C-O-" spacer of the L anion could make the two carboxylate groups coordinate to metal ions in different directions. In compounds 1-6 and 8-10, although each L anion bridges two metal cations, the two carboxylates can twist to bridge metal ions in different directions. In compounds 1-3, 9 and 10, the two carboxylates of each L anion link two metal ions in the same direction to form a dimeric unit. However, in compounds 4-6 and 8, the two carboxylates of each L anion connect two metal ions in different directions, yielding chain structures. Meanwhile, in 7 the two carboxylates of each L anion bridge three metal ions to generate a 2D 44-sql network. Noticeably, the coordination modes of the L anions are a key factor that influences the final structures of these compounds.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0130" view="all">In our previous work, two series of CCs based on related dicarboxylates, 4′-((3-carboxyphenoxy)methyl)biphenyl-2-carboxylic acid (3-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L) and 4′-((4-carboxyphenoxy)methyl)biphenyl-2-carboxylic acid (4-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L), have been synthesized . Obviously, the three dicarboxylic acids H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L, 3-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L and 4-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L possess the same backbones between the two carboxylates, but one carboxylate position is entirely different. As a result, the subunits of the CCs constructed by the three carboxylic acids are also slightly variable in structure. In most of the CCs based on the 3-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L and 4-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L ligands, the adjacent metal ions were linked by the 3-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L or 4-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L ligands to give a 1D chain. In contrast, in the current compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>10</ce:bold>, two L anions bridge two metal ions to afford a dimeric unit. It is evident that the structural difference in the subunits is highly dependent on the carboxylate positions of the three dicarboxylate ligands.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In our previous work, two series of CCs based on related dicarboxylates, 4'-((3-carboxyphenoxy)methyl)biphenyl-2-carboxylic acid (3-H2L) and 4'-((4-carboxyphenoxy)methyl)biphenyl-2-carboxylic acid (4-H2L), have been synthesized . Obviously, the three dicarboxylic acids H2L, 3-H2L and 4-H2L possess the same backbones between the two carboxylates, but one carboxylate position is entirely different. As a result, the subunits of the CCs constructed by the three carboxylic acids are also slightly variable in structure. In most of the CCs based on the 3-H2L and 4-H2L ligands, the adjacent metal ions were linked by the 3-H2L or 4-H2L ligands to give a 1D chain. In contrast, in the current compounds 1-3 and 10, two L anions bridge two metal ions to afford a dimeric unit. It is evident that the structural difference in the subunits is highly dependent on the carboxylate positions of the three dicarboxylate ligands.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st160">Effect of the N-donor ligands on the complex structures</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0135" view="all">In order to achieve CCs with various structure diversities, in this work carefully selected N-donor ligands were introduced into the reaction system as the auxiliary ligands. It is well established that the spacer length, flexibility and steric hindrance of the substituent groups of the N-donor ligands are mainly related to their complex structures . From the structures of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>7</ce:bold>, it can be seen that the N-donor ligands have a great influence on the structures of the compounds.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Effect of the N-donor ligands on the complex structures

In order to achieve CCs with various structure diversities, in this work carefully selected N-donor ligands were introduced into the reaction system as the auxiliary ligands. It is well established that the spacer length, flexibility and steric hindrance of the substituent groups of the N-donor ligands are mainly related to their complex structures . From the structures of compounds 1-4 and 7, it can be seen that the N-donor ligands have a great influence on the structures of the compounds.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0140" view="all">Compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> exhibit the effect of the spacer length of the N-donor ligands on their complex structures. In <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, three bis(imidazole) ligands with different spacer lengths (die, dib and bmimb) were utilized in the reactions, respectively. Although similar [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] units were formed in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, their final network structures are different. For example, in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, each [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] unit is linked by four die ligands to yield a 2D sheet structure with a Cd⋯Cd distance of 6.347<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. In contrast, in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, the longer bmimb ligand links two [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] dimers to afford a 2D layer with a Cd⋯Cd distance of 14.945<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, which is much longer than those found in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. In particular, the large interstices between the two [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] dimers result in interdigitation among adjacent layers, leading to the 2D<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3D interdigitated architecture of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Compounds 1-3 exhibit the effect of the spacer length of the N-donor ligands on their complex structures. In 1-3, three bis(imidazole) ligands with different spacer lengths (die, dib and bmimb) were utilized in the reactions, respectively. Although similar [Cd2(L)2] units were formed in 1-3, their final network structures are different. For example, in 1, each [Cd2(L)2] unit is linked by four die ligands to yield a 2D sheet structure with a Cd⋯Cd distance of 6.347Å. In contrast, in 3, the longer bmimb ligand links two [Cd2(L)2] dimers to afford a 2D layer with a Cd⋯Cd distance of 14.945Å, which is much longer than those found in 1 and 2. In particular, the large interstices between the two [Cd2(L)2] dimers result in interdigitation among adjacent layers, leading to the 2D→3D interdigitated architecture of 3.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0145" view="all">Compounds <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> show the effects of the steric hindrances of the substituent groups on their structures. Compared with the bimb ligand, the bmimb ligand possesses two extra methyl groups on the imidazole rings. In <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, the two carboxylate groups of the L ligand twist in different directions, bridging two Cd(II) atoms to generate a zigzag chain, which are further linked by the bimb ligands to yield a layer structure. However, when the bmimb ligand, with two extra methyl groups, was used instead of the bimb ligand under the similar synthetic condition, a structurally different compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> was obtained. In <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, two L ligands link two Cd(II) atoms to give a [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] unit, which are further connected by the bimb ligands, resulting in a 2D<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3D interdigitated architecture. On the other hand, when the N-donor bridging ligands were replaced by the N-donor chelating ligand phen, the different 2D 4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>-sql network of <ce:bold>7</ce:bold> was achieved. The chelating phen ligands are located on both sides of the [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] unit.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Compounds 3 and 4 show the effects of the steric hindrances of the substituent groups on their structures. Compared with the bimb ligand, the bmimb ligand possesses two extra methyl groups on the imidazole rings. In 4, the two carboxylate groups of the L ligand twist in different directions, bridging two Cd(II) atoms to generate a zigzag chain, which are further linked by the bimb ligands to yield a layer structure. However, when the bmimb ligand, with two extra methyl groups, was used instead of the bimb ligand under the similar synthetic condition, a structurally different compound 3 was obtained. In 3, two L ligands link two Cd(II) atoms to give a [Cd2(L)2] unit, which are further connected by the bimb ligands, resulting in a 2D→3D interdigitated architecture. On the other hand, when the N-donor bridging ligands were replaced by the N-donor chelating ligand phen, the different 2D 44-sql network of 7 was achieved. The chelating phen ligands are located on both sides of the [Cd2] unit.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st165">Effect of metal cations on the network structures</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0150" view="all">The coordination mode of the metal ion also plays a great effect on the structures of the complexes . The different coordination numbers of the metal cations are the main reason for the complex structure diversities. For example, in compounds <ce:bold>7</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>8</ce:bold>, the coordination number of the Cd(II)ion is larger than that of the Cu(II) ion. In <ce:bold>7</ce:bold>, there are five-coordinated Cd(II) ions which are connected by L anions and phen ligands to form a 2D network. However, the four-coordinated Cu(II) atoms are linked by L anions and phen ligands to generate a 1D chain in <ce:bold>8</ce:bold>. The effect of metal cations is further supported by compounds <ce:bold>9</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>10</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Effect of metal cations on the network structures

The coordination mode of the metal ion also plays a great effect on the structures of the complexes . The different coordination numbers of the metal cations are the main reason for the complex structure diversities. For example, in compounds 7 and 8, the coordination number of the Cd(II)ion is larger than that of the Cu(II) ion. In 7, there are five-coordinated Cd(II) ions which are connected by L anions and phen ligands to form a 2D network. However, the four-coordinated Cu(II) atoms are linked by L anions and phen ligands to generate a 1D chain in 8. The effect of metal cations is further supported by compounds 9 and 10.

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>319<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm) for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, 426<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>

elements.clean_text:
Luminescent properties

The luminescent properties of compounds with d10 metal centers have been extensively studied due to their potential applications . In this work, the luminescent properties of 1-5, 7 and 9 have been studied in the solid state at room temperature ( ). The emission spectra of 1-5, 7 and 9 display bands at 442nm (λ ex =313nm) for 1, 420nm (λ ex =318nm) for 2, 426nm (λ ex =319nm) for 3, 426nm (λ ex =320nm) for 4, 442nm (λ ex =323nm) for 5, 401nm (λ ex =312nm) for 7 and 414nm (λ ex =373nm) for 9 ( ). To understand the nature of such emission bands, the emission spectra of H2L and bmimb were measured ( and ), while the ones of die, dib, bimb, phen, and mtpy are known . The emission peaks of H2L, die, dib, bmimb, bimb, phen, and mtpy are located at 437, 400, 436, 467, 423, 380 and 399nm, respectively. These emissions may come from the π ∗ → n or π ∗ → π transition . The emission peaks of 1-4 and 5 are close to that of the free H2L ligand, so their luminescence can be assigned to intraligand emissions . The emission peaks of 7 and 9 are blue-shifted by 36 and 23nm, respectively, with respect to free H2L. The blue-shift may be attributed to the introduction of the rigid ligands (phen and mtpy) into the complex networks, which increases the conformational rigidity of the whole structures .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0160" view="all">Recently, some CCs with luminescent properties have shown potential application for the selectivity and sensitivity towards small molecules . Therefore, taking compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> as an example, experiments for detection of small molecule have been studied. Eight organic solvents (methanol, ethanol, DMF, acetonitrile, dichloromethane, trichloromethane, tetrahydrofuran and acetone) were selected as analytes. Three milligrams of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> was ground down and then immersed in the analytes. The final emulsions were obtained after treatment by ultrasonication for 30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min. All emulsions were measured under the same conditions (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>318<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm). The results show that the emission spectra of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are affected by different analytes to a different degree (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0060"></ce:float-anchor>). Especially, a significant quenching effect toward acetone was observed. The results show that compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is a potential luminescent sensory material for acetone. To investigate the mechanism of the quenching effect toward acetone, the absorption spectra of the different solvents were measured (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0065"></ce:float-anchor>). Obviously, acetone possesses a high absorbance in range 300–350<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, while the absorbances of the other solvents in this range are approximately zero. Because the exciting wavelength of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> lies in range 300–350<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, acetone can effectively absorb the exciting light energy. In other words, there is an energy transfer process between acetone and the light source energy, which results in the strong quenching effect of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> towards acetone.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Recently, some CCs with luminescent properties have shown potential application for the selectivity and sensitivity towards small molecules . Therefore, taking compound 2 as an example, experiments for detection of small molecule have been studied. Eight organic solvents (methanol, ethanol, DMF, acetonitrile, dichloromethane, trichloromethane, tetrahydrofuran and acetone) were selected as analytes. Three milligrams of 2 was ground down and then immersed in the analytes. The final emulsions were obtained after treatment by ultrasonication for 30min. All emulsions were measured under the same conditions (λ ex =318nm). The results show that the emission spectra of 2 are affected by different analytes to a different degree ( ). Especially, a significant quenching effect toward acetone was observed. The results show that compound 2 is a potential luminescent sensory material for acetone. To investigate the mechanism of the quenching effect toward acetone, the absorption spectra of the different solvents were measured ( ). Obviously, acetone possesses a high absorbance in range 300-350nm, while the absorbances of the other solvents in this range are approximately zero. Because the exciting wavelength of 2 lies in range 300-350nm, acetone can effectively absorb the exciting light energy. In other words, there is an energy transfer process between acetone and the light source energy, which results in the strong quenching effect of 2 towards acetone.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st175">Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0165" view="all">In summary, we have successfully synthesized ten CCs based on a new dicarboxylate ligand and various N-donor ligands under solvothermal conditions. These compounds display abundant 0D, 2D and 2D<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3D structural features. The results indicate that the structural diversity of these compounds can be tuned by different N-donor ligands and metal ions. elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we have successfully synthesized ten CCs based on a new dicarboxylate ligand and various N-donor ligands under solvothermal conditions. These compounds display abundant 0D, 2D and 2D→3D structural features. The results indicate that the structural diversity of these compounds can be tuned by different N-donor ligands and metal ions. The photoluminescent behavior of 2 suggests that these compounds may be good candidates for potential luminescent materials.

Syntheses of H2L and the complexes

Synthesis of H2L

A mixture of 2-hydroxy benzoic acid methyl ester (4.2g, 10mmol), NaOH (0.4g, 10mmol), 4-bromomethylbiphenyl-2'-carboxylic acid methyl ester (7.7g, 10mmol) and ethanol (100mL) was refluxed for 10h. The solution was cooled to room temperature, and NaOH (2.0g, 50mmol) dissolved in water (30mL) was added. After the mixture was refluxed for 8h, the alcohol was removed by rotary evaporation, then 150mL water was added and the pH value was adjusted to 2-3 using hydrochloric acid. The solid H2L was filtered off, washed with water and air-dried (yield 63%). Mp: 176.4-177.8°C. Anal. Calc. for C21H16O5 (M r =348.35): C, 72.41; H, 4.63. Found: C, 72.30; H, 4.77%. IR (cm-1): 3062(s), 1695(w), 1605(w), 1486(m), 1299(w), 1258(m), 866(s), 821(m). 1H NMR [500MHz, (CD3)2SO] δ, ppm: 5.24 (s, 2H), 7.02 (t, 1H), 7.23 (d, 1H), 7.34 (d, 2H), 7.39 (d, 1H), 7.45 (t, 1H), 7.49 (d, 1H), 7.52 (d, 2H), 7.58 (t, 1H), 7.66 (d, 1H), 7.71 (d, 1H), 12.71 (s, 2H).

Synthesis of {[Cd(L)(die)]⋅2/3H2O} n  (1)

A mixture of H2L (35mg, 0.1mmol), Cd(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O (27mg, 0.1mmol), die (16mg, 0.1mmol), DMF (6mL) and ethanol (3mL) was sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave reactor (15mL) and heated at 120°C for 3days. Colorless crystals of 1 were obtained in a 24% yield based on Cd(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O. Anal. Calc. for C29H25.33CdN4O5.67 (M r =632.93): C, 55.08; H, 4.04; N, 8.86. Found: C, 54.82; H, 4.21; N, 8.63%. IR (cm-1): 3447(s), 3106(m), 1598(w), 1556(w), 1401(w), 1251(m), 1236(w), 1128(s), 863(m).

Synthesis of [Cd(L)(dib)] n  (2)

The preparation of 2 was similar to that of 1 except dib (19mg 0.1mmol) was used instead of die. Colorless crystals of 2 were obtained in a 33% yield based on Cd(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O. Anal. Calc. for C31H28CdN4O5 (M r =648.97): C, 57.37; H, 4.35; N, 8.63. Found: C, 57.58; H, 4.23; N, 8.51%. IR (cm-1): 3454(w), 3059(m), 2869(s), 1604(w), 1448(w), 1398(w), 1275(w), 1160(m), 1003(w), 858(w), 821(s), 760(w), 713(w).

Synthesis of [Cd(L)(bmimb)] n  (3)

The preparation of 3 was similar to that of 1 except bmimb (27mg, 0.1mmol) was used instead of die. Colorless crystals of 3 were obtained in a 37% yield based on Cd(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O. Anal. Calc. for C37H32CdN4O5 (M r =725.07): C, 61.29; H, 4.45; N, 7.73. Found: C, 61.50; H, 4.25; N, 7.85%. IR (cm-1): 3420(m), 3062(s), 1603(w), 1536(m). 1465(w), 1383(w), 1250(m), 1154(s), 1046(s), 813(m), 760(w).

Synthesis of {[Cd(L)(bimb)]⋅1/2EtOH} n  (4)

The preparation of 4 was similar to that of 1 except bimb (24mg, 0.1mmol) was used instead of die. Colorless crystals of 4 were obtained in a 23% yield based on Cd(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O. Anal. Calc. for C36H31CdN4O5.5 (M r =720.05): C, 60.05; H, 4.34; N, 7.78. Found: C, 59.85; H, 4.65; N, 7.94%. IR (cm-1): 3424(s), 3125(m), 2864(s), 1600(w), 1551(w), 1318(m), 1279(w), 1150(s), 941(m), 856(m), 764(w), 676(s).

Synthesis of [Zn(L)(bimb)] n  (5)

The preparation of 5 was similar to that of 4 except Zn(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O (22mg, 0.1mmol) was used instead of Cd(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O. Colorless crystals of 5 were obtained in a 29% yield based on Zn(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O. Anal. Calc. for C35H28N4O5Zn (M r =649.98): C, 64.67; H, 4.34; N, 8.62. Found: C, 64.84; H, 4.45; N, 8.43%. IR (cm-1): 3371(m), 3058(s), 2893(s), 1546(w), 1449(w), 1393(w), 1319(s), 1241(w), 1148(w), 1045(m), 1003(m), 854(w), 795(s), 727(w), 676(m).

Synthesis of [Co(L)(bimb)] n  (6)

The preparation of 6 was similar to that of 4 except Co(CH3COO)2⋅4H2O (25mg, 0.1mmol) was used instead of Cd(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O. Pink crystals of 6 were obtained in an 18% yield based on Co(CH3COO)2⋅4H2O. Anal. Calc. for C35H28CoN4O5 (M r =643.54): C, 65.32; H, 4.39; N, 8.71. Found: C, 65.44; H, 4.31; N, 8.53%. IR (cm-1): 3402(s), 3029(s), 1671(s), 1600(w), 1516(w), 1445(w), 1277(w), 1235(w), 1109(w), 1031(m), 939(s), 858(m), 751(w), 678(s), 622(s) (m).

Synthesis of {[Cd(L)(phen)]⋅EtOH} n  (7)

A mixture of H2L (35mg, 0.1mmol), Cd(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O (27mg, 0.1mmol), phen (20mg, 0.1mmol) and ethanol (8mL) was sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave reactor (15mL) and heated at 140°C for 3days. Colorless crystals of 7 were obtained in a 30% yield based on Cd(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O. Anal. Calc. for C35H28CdN2O6 (M r =684.99): C, 61.37; H, 4.12; N, 4.09. Found: C, 61.08; H, 4.25; N, 4.21%. IR (cm-1): 3260(m), 3062(m), 1604(w), 1564(s), 1397(w), 1284(w), 1145(s), 1042(s), 914(m), 800(s).

Synthesis of [Cu(L)(phen)] n  (8)

The preparation of 8 was similar to that of 7 except Cu(CH3COO)2⋅H2O (20mg, 0.1mmol) was used instead of Cd(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O. Blue crystals of 8 were obtained in a 41% yield based on Cu(CH3COO)2⋅H2O. Anal. Calc. for C33H22CuN2O5 (M r =590.07): C, 67.17; H, 3.76; N, 4.75. Found: C, 67.29; H, 3.58; N, 4.84%. IR (cm-1): 3054(s), 1593(w), 1538(w), 1476(w), 1401(w), 1378(w), 1215(m), 1071(m), 1003(m), 897(s), 835(m), 818(w), 752(w), 668(s).

Synthesis of [Zn(L)(mtpy)] n  (9)

The preparation of 9 was similar to that of 7 except Zn(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O (22mg, 0.1mmol) and mtpy (33mg, 0.1mmol) were used instead of Cd(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O and phen. Colorless crystals of 9 were obtained in a 45% yield based on Zn(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O. Anal. Calc. for C43H31N3O5Zn (M r =735.08): C, 70.26; H, 4.25; N, 5.72. Found: C, 70.01; H, 4.35; N, 5.86%. IR (cm-1): 3451(s), 3055(s), 1594(w), 1476(w), 1401(w), 1251(m), 1159(s), 1091(s), 1004(m), 897(s), 862(m).

Synthesis of [Ni(L)(mtpy)]⋅1/2H2O (10)

The preparation of 10 was similar to that of 9 except Ni(CH3COO)2⋅4H2O (25mg, 0.1mmol) was used instead of Zn(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O. Green crystals of 10 were obtained in a 52% yield based on Ni(CH3COO)2⋅4H2O. Anal. Calc. for C43H32N3NiO5.5 (M r =737.43): C, 70.04; H, 4.37; N, 5.70. Found: C, 69.79; H, 4.20; N, 5.78%. IR (cm-1): 3627(s), 1604(w), 1558(w), 1446(m), 1360(w), 1148(s), 1108(m), 1030(s), 843(m), 751(m), 713(s), 623(s).

cln_elements.clean_text:
Luminescent properties

The luminescent properties of compounds with d10 metal centers have been extensively studied due to their potential applications . In this work, the luminescent properties of 1-5, 7 and 9 have been studied in the solid state at room temperature ( ). The emission spectra of 1-5, 7 and 9 display bands at 442nm (λ ex =313nm) for 1, 420nm (λ ex =318nm) for 2, 426nm (λ ex =319nm) for 3, 426nm (λ ex =320nm) for 4, 442nm (λ ex =323nm) for 5, 401nm (λ ex =312nm) for 7 and 414nm (λ ex =373nm) for 9 ( ). To understand the nature of such emission bands, the emission spectra of H2L and bmimb were measured ( and ), while the ones of die, dib, bimb, phen, and mtpy are known . The emission peaks of H2L, die, dib, bmimb, bimb, phen, and mtpy are located at 437, 400, 436, 467, 423, 380 and 399nm, respectively. These emissions may come from the π ∗ → n or π ∗ → π transition . The emission peaks of 1-4 and 5 are close to that of the free H2L ligand, so their luminescence can be assigned to intraligand emissions . The emission peaks of 7 and 9 are blue-shifted by 36 and 23nm, respectively, with respect to free H2L. The blue-shift may be attributed to the introduction of the rigid ligands (phen and mtpy) into the complex networks, which increases the conformational rigidity of the whole structures .
